title: Seven Steeples
author: Baume, Sara
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 3.52 is an absolutely spot-on average rating from the folks here at goodreads What we have here is a couple moving out of Dublin to go be wasters in s3.52 is an absolutely spot-on average rating from the folks here at goodreads What we have here is a couple moving out of Dublin to go be wasters in some house in the middle of nowhere, and then 250 pages of in-depth descriptions of their domestic habits, their dogs and their gradual descent into total squalor. I'd put the reading experience in the same bracket as Nicholson Baker's The Mezzanine, in that at times it was completely beautiful, but if I was even slightly tired I kinda wanted to die. I have so much respect for how much time this must have taken to write, how much thought went into each word selection, paragraph structure, the exact syllabic count of each sentence. The manipulation of the language is perfect at times. When this book Hits you can really just sink into the prose and feel so cosy and at home like you're swimmin around in a cup of tea. You also gotta admire Baume's commitment to FINDING all this domestic detail and bundling it into a novel where, literally, Absolutely Nothing Happens.That kinda saggy middle of the book was definitely where I struggled, for that reason. I started to get a bit frustrated that really nothing, NOthing was going to happen. The descriptions start to feel a tad repetitive. There's not really any tension in the relationship, despite the sense of violence and looming threat in a lot of the imagery. Maybe Baume could have made the same points about The Simple Life in less time. bUt i guess all this I've said is kinda the point. Sometimes 8 years just pass. Sometimes the same things do just happen. Sometimes two people do just love each other. Yeah yeah nah yeah tbf there may not be tension but the slow transition of the couple from being naive young #vanlife people to becoming basically the same person is executed in such a subtle, haunting and tender way.Hmmmm okay okay the more I get into this  the more I think 3.52 is actually too low?? Sara Baume might actually be a genius. Fuck....more

title: Dignity
author: Conran, Alys
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 3.5. I was rooting for this book so hard. It's a novel with loads of highly ambitious elements that shouldn't work but kinda do, and other more conven3.5. I was rooting for this book so hard. It's a novel with loads of highly ambitious elements that shouldn't work but kinda do, and other more conventional elements that should work pretty easily but feel kinda off. Basically we got a very old lady in like the equivalent of Southend refusing to leave her home, her young n unexpectedly pregnant carer, and THEN her mother way back in colonial India getting pregnant and having a bad time. Also then the old lady in her childhood later on. All in first person. It's a lot. The main hook for me was seeing how Conran was gonna pull it off. And tbf she did a pretty good job of it.I think there are some problems with the writing itself, mostly the dialogue. I felt like the robot devil in futurama going 'you cant just have your characters announce how they feel! That makes me feel angry!' There definitely could have been something quite phenomenal here had the author reigned herself in a little bit and let the stories speak for themselves more. BUT the characters and the drama really grabbed me, and the rapid shifting of perspective, which sHOULD have fucked any prospect of momentum, actually made it a really engaging and pacey read. Bonus points for all the wild psychadelic imagery just sandblasted onto the page outta nowhere....more

title: Wednesday's Child: Stories
author: Li, Yiyun
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: God this was such a treat. I will always associate listening to this collection with such a special month or so of my life. Yiyun Li proving again n aGod this was such a treat. I will always associate listening to this collection with such a special month or so of my life. Yiyun Li proving again n again she is one of the most original contemporary writers. The way she layers her stories, the way she goes deeper and deeper into memory until you get to one tiny nugget of Story in the middle, it's such an engaging and challenging reading experience, but one that feels so sweet and comforting. Li seems to be grappling here with the impossibility of remembering How Things Happened, how something was said, how you felt during the big moments of your life.It's her power of observation and her kinda ghostly, just slightly strange way of presenting people that really draws us into all these lives. She makes the everyday feel surreal, the unbelievable feel believable. I'd recommend giving this book to someone who is a mother or maybe a child. There's so much love and loss and uncertainty on show here. It's good for welling up on the train. It's good for looking at the cranes on the harbourside....more

title: Black Sugar
author: Bonnefoy, Miguel
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Yeah man this is decent. Some old ass pirate treasure gets buried deep under a Venezuelan village and three hundred years later everyone's still thinkYeah man this is decent. Some old ass pirate treasure gets buried deep under a Venezuelan village and three hundred years later everyone's still thinkin about it. 'Wouldnt it be nice to find the treasure,' say this one family. 'Let's pursue this in a very healthy and normal manner.' It's a technically solid story and a good easy to follow allegory for the colonisation of this part of the Americas. It doesn't really do anything wrong, but it doesn't really lurch to any great heights either. I think I would have liked Bonnefoy to get a bit closer to the characters and the setting and to really build up the sense of the community here. As it is, the more stood-back, tale-round-a-fire style of storytelling made it feel a little bit meat n potatoes. There was an opportunity here for something with much more emotional force had the author (treasure joke coming this is a treasure joke okay here it is treasure joke) dug a little deeper....more

title: How to Kill Your Family
author: Mackie, Bella
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is a pathetic novel. I'm taking it as an extreme testament to my mental strength that I stuck this out to the end. The writing is poor. The storyThis is a pathetic novel. I'm taking it as an extreme testament to my mental strength that I stuck this out to the end. The writing is poor. The story is poor. It's barely even her family that she's killing and she doesn't even kill them all!!! The two most important ones just die by themselves!!! I would tick the 'my  contains spoilers' box but this book isnt worthy of it. Grace has hands down got to be the most lethargic and boring serial killer ever. Even shE can't be arsed. Absolutely zero personality. Like,,, mAybe this is meant to show how detached and driven she is to murder these people, but most of the time the only thing she's killing is the buzz. The humour is cynical and so unoriginal it's nauseating. Like, yes British people love queueing. Ha ha ha who even likes bountys. 'I loved this book,' says Richard Osman. So now we know for sure never to give the Thursday Murder Club a chance. This really could be the book that pushes me to being one of those contradictorians who assumes anything that sells well must be bad. I didn't want to be this way but this is the content that we are dealing with. You did this to me. It's just the exact opposite of good writing. It's so stupidly lazy at every turn and just wastes everybody's time. Who the fUck was editing this??? How can you just let a mysterious new brother magically appear at the end to wrap up the loose ends??? Loose ends that even with a basic amount of plot management wouldnt have had to be there in the first place??? Did an infant write this????? The euphoria I feel to be shot of this shite heap is so palpable I could cry. I can't believe I sold this to someone in my bookshop using the phrase 'like a millennial Kill Bill'. I'm going to actually throw up....more

title: Nagasaki
author: Faye, Éric
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I work in a secondhand book shop that also buys paperbacks off people and a nice old lady sold me this and was like 'I read it in an afternoon it's reI work in a secondhand book shop that also buys paperbacks off people and a nice old lady sold me this and was like 'I read it in an afternoon it's really good promise' so I read it in an afternoon and unfortunately it's not very good and that woman was a liar. It's a little story about a guy who discovers that a woman has been living secretly in his house for over a year, eating all his yoghurt without him realising. Then when she gets found out and arrested he really misses her even though he was never really aware of her. It's actually quite a good concept but the writing is just bad on a fundamental level. Lots of cliches and bizarre similes. Lots of big profound statements on the meaningless of the universe that just come out of nowhere. Also keeps changing tense and perspective for some reason? It's like the writer is close to isolating a good story about loneliness and alienation, but doesnt seem to realise it at all and just bulldozes on into this weird narrative about how everyone should be allowed to have a key to their childhood home after they move out (????) I'm not joking that's the note the book ends on. It ends with this deranged letter from the intruder being like 'and the big reason why I stayed in your house so long.... is that I wanted to lol. Also I'm addicted to drugs. One time I was in a paramilitary group. Anyway, bye!' That's literally it like it's one of the wildest endings to a books I've ever read. Also the author has clearly never been to Nagasaki or Japan in general it's so funny when he's all like 'I bought a /bento box/ at lunch and ate... /rice/'. King shit level of no research whatsoever. Okay this is a longer  than I anticipated but I'm actually just kinda fascinated by this book. Who published it? What is this French academy that gave it an award??? It's right in that uncanny, In Time (dir. Andrew Niccol, 2011) sweetspot between almost good and actually terrible which you all know sends my greasefire brain into absolute haywire. Was gonna bring this back to my shop but maybe this is one for Jay Fox to check over. Something's up here. What is it....more

title: To Battersea Park
author: Hensher, Philip
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Sat in Auckland airport waiting for my ears to pop, thinkin about the sheer gall of my man Philip Hensher.For a long time I felt like we shouldn't be Sat in Auckland airport waiting for my ears to pop, thinkin about the sheer gall of my man Philip Hensher.For a long time I felt like we shouldn't be writing about covid, mostly for emotionally driven reasons, but I feel like this novel is a really great way to dip the toe into that whole trauma bath, a novel which, in itself, is an exploration of how the fuck we can write about this period in a way that's remotely meaningful. It's four parts, four different lockdown stories written in four different styles, essentially being like 'how about this', 'no actually how about this', 'or this', 'actually forget it'. It's really interesting to see Philip fucking with the ideas in real time. Like, he does a really good job of making everything as boring and banal as possible, then seems to just go 'actually fuck this someone's gotta get stabbed'. Defo a bit wanky in places when he starts writing about the craft of the story during the story - felt like he could have left all that to speak for itself - but I respect the ambition to fuck with the form, and ultimately each story is really rewarding in the way they slowly unfurl and pull threads together. On the whole our Phil uses covid really effectively as a means of exploring how little we know about people's private lives. LOVE the ending as well what an absolutely wild left turn into like a whole other genre so out of character lmao king shitKinda unrelated but feels like this is for fans of videos that explain old London tube maps...more

title: The Shipping News
author: Proulx, Annie
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Twat. Back of the net. So so glad I took the whole month to read this. This is an all-timer. Annie Proulx's The Shipping News asks a simple question. Twat. Back of the net. So so glad I took the whole month to read this. This is an all-timer. Annie Proulx's The Shipping News asks a simple question. How can you get over your terrible wife dying in a car crash when everyone around you is completely deranged?? The Newfoundland Proulx gives us is fucked. Violence is everywhere. The world is depraved and scary. Yet the overall reading experience is so calming, so immersive, each paragraph like another wave coming into shore. Quoyle is just tryna do right by his kids and grill a few squid burgers. I love him. I love him. I love him forever. The grOWth each of these characters go through... and without the need for overly punctuated plot beats, just through life unfurling in its own unpredictable way. This is a tour de force of the nothing-happens genre. They even find a severed head in a suitcase and it drives the plot nowhere. The language! The dialogue! Just completely off the rails! I've read and loved Annie before but she is just so completely On from the get go here. You won't find a single cliche in the whole book, and if there is a familiar scenario to us (folks in the diner arguing about the way things used to be) she comes at it with such flair and such imagination that it cant feel like anything other than real life. It's just joyous, chaotic and explosive writing. Fully deserving of all the prizes it won in '94. Should be talked about more today. The work of a genius at the top of her game....more

review: I came for easy trash and I got what I wanted. BUT within the trashiness there's still bangin family dynamics and well-rounded characters who I care aI came for easy trash and I got what I wanted. BUT within the trashiness there's still bangin family dynamics and well-rounded characters who I care about?? It's a win-win. This feels like a real celebration of YA and romance tropes and the way online fanfiction has contributed to both. Yeah it's kinda yucky sweet, but there are moments here where Rowell really captures the most joyful parts of being a writer. I so appreciate how self-indulgent this is and how much fun she's having. It made me want to get back to my book and finish it. Also made me weirdly nostalgic for when Tesco used to open at midnight for the new Harry Potter books. What were that all about??...more

title: Rest and Be Thankful
author: Glass, Emma
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 3.5 - A really poignant and freaky little novel that deserves to graduate from Jay Fox's Academy for Women At Their Fucking Limit. Personally I'm just3.5 - A really poignant and freaky little novel that deserves to graduate from Jay Fox's Academy for Women At Their Fucking Limit. Personally I'm just not a huge fan of first person present tense. I get why it was needed here to convey the relentless one-after-the-otherness of the job, but the cadence was just a little too stop-starty for me to REALLY get into it.But that shouldn't take away from the punch of the content itself. This book really powerfully and emotionally captures how absolutely fucked it is to be a paediatric nurse. I'm a huge fan of the syngery Glass creates between burnout and psychological n supernatural horror. Plenty of real blow-out-your-cheeks moments. Man oh man....more

title: Burning Bright
author: Steinbeck, John
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I ain't gonna lie I'm not entirely sure what John was goin for here Always try to read a new Steinbeck every summer. Burning Bright has the emotive chI ain't gonna lie I'm not entirely sure what John was goin for here Always try to read a new Steinbeck every summer. Burning Bright has the emotive characters, it has the stunning one liners, it has flashes of the breathtaking, simple descriptions of setting that we've come to expect from the goat. I guess the attempt to clang together the forms of the play and the novella make the scenes feel a little static. It's not quite one thing or the other. The dialogue isn't quite compelling enough to sustain the whole thing, and the settings aren't quite rich enough to get fully absorbed in.A lot of that comes down to the changes in the setting. So what's happening here is the same plot is carrying on chronologically, but for some reason all the characters keep changing jobs in between. It's like one story told in three parallel universes, one at the circus, one at a farm, one on a boat. And I just dont know... why. Lmao. Is it something to do with the play's concluding message that every kind of person has a responsibility to raise every child? Or was Steinbeck just fuckin about? I respect it. I just dont know what it's adding. Fair play though it was fun. Some pretty wild gymnastics to get to its weirdly moral dismount. Friend Ed definitely entering the list of favourite Steinbeck characters. 'It is so easy a thing to give - only great men have the courage and courtesy and, yes, the generosity to receive'...more

title: A Man Called Ove
author: Backman, Fredrik*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: **spoiler alert** 2.5A better title for this would be 'And Then Everyone Clapped'. I've never seen so many extremely straightforward and overly-conven**spoiler alert** 2.5A better title for this would be 'And Then Everyone Clapped'. I've never seen so many extremely straightforward and overly-convenient plot resolutions in one book before. But that's just one of my issues with A Man Called Ove. The others are:The plot structure feels so much like watching every mid hollywood film ever, in that the trajectory of the story is so obvious from the start that reading it just feels like going through the motions. As soon as the cat rocks up I'm like '...yep'. Like, yeah it's light, it's cosy, but I'm actively SIGHING every time a by-the-numbers plotbeat is hit. Sometimes a layer of predictability in a story is a good thing but... mate. We are in Skim City.Why do we keep driving to the hospital?Any social issue that's raised feels like cultural boxticking. The style! FUCK! Backman is obsessed with utterly useless similes. I've read the words 'as if' so many times this week I think I now have diahorrea. Hold on let me turn to literally a random page.... 'Ove stares back at it [the cat] with a suspicion normally reserved for a cat that has rung his doorbell with a bible in its paws, like a jehovah's witness'... like.... okay??? I'm not joking there's at least two of these every page and none of them made me laugh. And THAT'S THE THING with this book lads;::;;:: at its core there's actually a really important and meaningful story here about masculinity and loneliness, and a really valuable emotional reshaping of the miserable bastard down the road. Objectively, there are heartwarming moments here. Some stunning chapters that exhibit a real wonderful tenderness. But these moments are just getting smothered by so much BULLSHIT. Stop fuCKing around!!! Stand up for your work!! A million people are buying this and you're emBARRASSING yourself!!!!God the dialogue when there's like five characters in the room. Nightmarish. Didnt happen of the year award goes to 300 people rocking up to Ove's funeral. Dude knew like ten people.Do not get me wrong (do not). Love kindness, me. Really rate that shit. But writers like Ronan Hession are doing this sorta thing with infinite more nuance and intrigue. You know what fuck it maybe this is just 2 stars. Fuck the .5 I'm rattled now. It's so irritating that any time it's good feels like a trick. Don't disrespect me like this, Fredrick Backman. I'll sue you. I don't care anymore....more

review: Yep. That is a Book.You guys know by now that for me good writing is all about empathy. Mary Beth Keane KNOWS her characters so well. There's such a lYep. That is a Book.You guys know by now that for me good writing is all about empathy. Mary Beth Keane KNOWS her characters so well. There's such a lovely awareness of why they do... bad things. Why anybody does bad things. No one's emotions are thrown to the curb or handled with anything less than upmost care. This is a novel about second chances, how we give them and how we take them. Any time Anne or George are on screen we are sOARING. They are perfect. Come up to me in the street and say their names and I will talk to you for half an hour. Gorgeous prose also.Only thing holding it back is that it's possibly a bit TOO bleak sometimes, to the point that it feels a little less believable. 90% of the time tho the strength of this is just how real and completely normal it all feels. Like this could've happened down the road. The tried and tested sad people in New York formula works yet again....more

title: The Island of Missing Trees
author: Shafak, Elif*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 3.5 - It's the strength of The Story that sustains this for sure. Romeo & Juliet type love story set around the troubles in Cyprus in 1974 and the aft3.5 - It's the strength of The Story that sustains this for sure. Romeo & Juliet type love story set around the troubles in Cyprus in 1974 and the aftermath of it. Stunning and very emotional engagement with the setting, brilliantly researched and brought to life. The significance of food was a winner for me. Definitely always looked forward to opening up the book.The dialogue... is bad. And the chapters told from the fig tree's perspective do feel quite preachy most of the time. And also I feel like it was doing a lot of cultural box-ticking like,,, 'yup we mentioned mental health okay good' BUT the exploration of inherited trauma and the way the fragments of the story come together make for a really compelling and rewarding read on the whole. Literally made me go out for Turkish food last week so the vibes are strong....more

I love this little Irish community.It's one of the best-presented stories about human kindness I've read in recent times. title: The Mermaid of Black Conch
author: Roffey, Monique*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Very skimmable, which is kinda a good and a bad thing. I can see why something like this won the Costa prize. It's '''literary''' in that it presents Very skimmable, which is kinda a good and a bad thing. I can see why something like this won the Costa prize. It's '''literary''' in that it presents themes of deeply entrenched colonialism and the objectification of women's bodies, but through the extremely palatable lens of a sexy fantasy mermaid romance. Like,,, it's gonna be on people's coffee tables. Definitely felt like this novel had been overly hacked-down to make it more digestible. And some of the writing felt a bit shortcutty. But I also liked that it was quick, so I cant have it both ways. I AM a big fan of the 'realistic' portrayal of the mermaid and all the piss and shit and scaley mess. Like, could you imagine actually being half person half fish that would be fucking disgusting....more

title: Must I Go
author: Li, Yiyun
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Now THIS is a Vibes Novel. Never come across a book so well sustained by its style and narrative voice.Getting a character to annotate another charactNow THIS is a Vibes Novel. Never come across a book so well sustained by its style and narrative voice.Getting a character to annotate another character's memoir for two thirds of a novel is... so fascinating. I was sceptical that it could work for that long. But here we are. It's Li's level of observation and just like the chop of her sentences that make it absolutely bang. It's also refreshing to see a book develop characters with so few visuals. It's all voice voice voice here. The trade off is that some of the cast of this big, complicated family are cloudier than others, but the ones who shine we get to know in such a gradual and organic way. It just simmers along so nicely. Hits good emotional moments without knocking itself unbalanced. It's definitely not a book for everyone, but I could have happily hung out with it for a few more hundred pages....more

title: Hamnet
author: O'Farrell, Maggie*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is such a good combination of brilliant research and brilliant imagination. For Maggie to piece together such a vivid and universal story about fThis is such a good combination of brilliant research and brilliant imagination. For Maggie to piece together such a vivid and universal story about family and grief around so few historical records is so impressive. The world she creates is so strong, oftentimes due to how well described everything is. It's such a stimulating novel, sensorily, and the aura that conjures makes the drifts into ideas of the supernatural work really well. This book is very much haunted. There were times when I did struggle a little bit with the style, but that's mainly because I'm a baby who needs less commas and more dialogue when I'm feelin sleepy. Another banger. 2023 stay winning tbh....more

title: All About Love: New Visions
author: hooks, bell
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 2.5 (have a class on this next week so had to briefly put Jane Eyre down) - In its strongest passages, this is very nice, easy to read, and relatively2.5 (have a class on this next week so had to briefly put Jane Eyre down) - In its strongest passages, this is very nice, easy to read, and relatively cosy. In its weakest, it's too nice, too easy and too cosy. On the whole, I don't think it does any harm to reaffirm ourselves with the concepts central to being a kind and loving person. Like, I raised a few smiles. I underlined a few quotes. But I do think, for this to be a Really worthwhile read, it has to do more than that. It has to be more radical. It has its moments of daring, but on the whole this was much too heteronormative and much too Americocentric a focus to offer any insights all that new or challenging about love. Mostly, it's just a long-winded way of saying 'just be sound yano'....more
